questions.prompt: The Brouwer Fixed Point Theorem states:
options: Every continuous function has a fixed point
Every continuous function from Dⁿ to itself has a fixed point
Every contraction has a unique fixed point
Every homeomorphism has a fixed point
questions.explanation: Brouwer: Every continuous map f: Dⁿ → Dⁿ (n-disk to itself) has a fixed point. This doesn't apply to all continuous functions.

questions.prompt: Fixed point theorems have applications in economics and game theory.
questions.explanation: True. Fixed point theorems (Brouwer, Kakutani) are fundamental in proving existence of Nash equilibria and economic equilibria.

questions.explanation: A manifold is a topological space that is locally homeomorphic to Euclidean space ℝⁿ near each point.

questions.prompt: The circle S¹ and the line ℝ are homeomorphic.
questions.explanation: False. S¹ is compact but ℝ is not. Homeomorphisms preserve compactness, so they cannot be homeomorphic.

questions.prompt: Homotopy is an equivalence relation where:
options: Two continuous maps can be continuously deformed into each other
Two spaces have the same dimension
questions.explanation: Maps f, g: X → Y are homotopic if there exists a continuous deformation H: X × [0,1] → Y with H(·, 0) = f and H(·, 1) = g.

questions.prompt: The fundamental group π₁(X, x₀) is always abelian.
questions.explanation: False. Many spaces have non-abelian fundamental groups. For example, π₁ of the figure-eight is the free group on two generators, which is non-abelian.

questions.prompt: The fundamental group of the circle S¹ is:
questions.explanation: π₁(S¹) ≅ ℤ. Loops around the circle are classified by their winding number, an integer.

questions.prompt: A simply connected space is one where:
options: The space is path connected and π₁ is trivial
Every loop can be contracted to a point
questions.explanation: A space is simply connected if it is path connected and every loop can be contracted to a point (π₁ is trivial).

questions.prompt: ℝⁿ is simply connected for all n ≥ 1.
questions.explanation: True. All Euclidean spaces ℝⁿ are simply connected (path connected with trivial fundamental group).
Knot theory studies embeddings of circles (S¹) in 3-dimensional space ℝ³, up to ambient isotopy.

questions.prompt: Algebraic topology assigns to each space:
questions.explanation: Algebraic topology associates algebraic objects (like groups, homology groups, cohomology rings) to topological spaces to study them.

questions.prompt: Homotopy equivalent spaces have isomorphic fundamental groups.
questions.explanation: True. The fundamental group is a homotopy invariant. If X ≃ Y (homotopy equivalent), then π₁(X) ≅ π₁(Y).

questions.prompt: A covering space p: E → B satisfies:
options: p is surjective and each point in B has an evenly covered neighborhood
questions.explanation: A covering map is surjective and locally looks like projection from a disjoint union. Each point has a neighborhood evenly covered by p.

questions.prompt: The universal covering space of S¹ is ℝ.
questions.explanation: True. ℝ is the universal cover of S¹ via the exponential map p: ℝ → S¹ given by t ↦ e^(2πit).

questions.prompt: Which spaces are NOT homotopy equivalent?
options: S¹ and the boundary of a square
A coffee cup and a donut (torus)
questions.explanation: S¹ and S² are not homotopy equivalent: π₁(S¹) = ℤ but π₁(S²) = 0. Options (a), (b), (c) are all homotopy equivalent pairs.
